title: Book: Alexander Stepanov's From Mathematics To Generic Programming

questions.answer: A divisor of n other than n itself.
The sum of all proper divisors of n.
A number that is the sum of its proper divisors.
Sum of the first n positive integers.
A number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself.
A number that has positive divisors other than 1 and itself.
A prime number that is one less than a power of two.
A prime number that is one more than a power of two.
Two numbers that have no common divisors greater than 1.
The number of positive integers less than n that are coprime with n.
Composite number n, greater than 1, whose coprimes up to n satisfy b^(n-1) == 1 mod n.

questions.answer: If p is prime, then for any 0 < a < p there is a number 0 < b < p such that ab = mp + 1, meaning a and b cancel modulo p.
If p is prime, then for any 0 < a < p, a^2 = mp + 1, if a = 1 or a = p - 1.

answerDetail.text:
A natural number n > 1 is a prime number if and only if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                <semantics>
                <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

                <mo stretchy="false">(</mo>
                <mi>n</mi>
                <mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
                <mn>1</mn>
                <mo stretchy="false">)</mo>
                <mo>!</mo>
                <mtext> </mtext>
                <mo>≡<!-- ≡ --></mo>
                <mtext> </mtext>
                <mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
                <mn>1</mn>
                <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                <mspace width="1em"></mspace>
                <mo stretchy="false">(</mo>
                <mi>mod</mi>
                <mspace width="0.333em"></mspace>
                <mi>n</mi>
                <mo stretchy="false">)</mo>
                </mrow>
                </mstyle>
                </mrow>
                </semantics>
                </math>

questions.answer: Grouping can change. For instance, addition: (a + b) + c == a + (b + c).
Order can change. For instance, addition: a + b == b + a. Matrix multiplication does not commute.
Operations can be applied to members of a group. For instance, multiplication over addition: a × (b + c)  =  a × b + a × c.
a related to b and b related to c implies a related to c. For instance, less than: If a < b and b < c, then a < c. Or, for instance, equality: If a == b and b == c, then a == c.
Related to itself. For instance, equality: a == a.
Related in both directions. For instance, equality: if a == b then b == a.
Associative, Commutative
Associative, Commutative, Distributive (over addition).
A set with an operation, an inverse operation, an identity constant e, and with associativity, identity and cancellation axioms.
A group whose operation is commutative.
An abelian group whose operation is addition.
An abelian group whose operation is multiplication.
A set with an operation, an identity constant e, and with associativity and identity axioms.
A set with an operation, and with associativity.
A subset of a group that is itself a group.
A subset of a group that is itself a group.
A group with a finite number of elements.
For any finite group G, the order (number of elements) of every subgroup H of G divides the order of G.
Integers
Natural Numbers
Real Numbers
Rational Numbers
Complex Numbers
Prime Remainder Fields
A complex number whose real and imaginary parts are both integers.
A complex number that is a root of some monic polynomial with coefficients in the set of integers.
A complex number whose real and imaginary parts are both integers.
A set with the addition and multiplication operations.
A ring for which xy = yx.
A commutative ring that can be endowed with an Euclidean function.
A element of a ring, for which there is a xn X^-1 such that x(x^-1) = (x^-1)x = 1. For instance, 1 and -1 in the ring of integers.
A element x of a ring, which is not = 0, and for which there is a y, also not = 0, for which xy = 0. For example in the ring of remainders modulo 6, the zero divisors are 2 and 3.
A commutative ring that has no zero divisors.
Absolute value
The degree
The complex norm
A polynomial where the coefficient of the highest order term is 1.
An integral domain where every nonzero element is invertible.
A subset of a field that is itself a field.
A subfield different from itself.
A field that does not have a proper subfield.
Integers
Rational Numbers
Assume the opposite of the original conjecture and show that this would lead to a contradiction.
Prove that it is true for the first element (basis) and prove that it is true for successors (inductive step).
If n items are put into m containers, with n > m > 0, then at least one container must contain more than one item.
